items.title: Obama’s Chance for a Fresh Start on a Climate-Smart Energy Quest
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: President Obama’s inaugural address stresses the need to press on energy frontiers and cut climate risks.

items.title: Boeing’s Battery Problems Cast Doubt on Appraisal of New Technologies
items.author: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew
items.abstract: The 787’s difficulties have raised questions about how regulators certify new technology and how they balance advances in design and engineering with safety.

items.title: Happiness, Beyond the Data
items.author: By Gary Gutting
items.abstract: Our first-person experience and reflection can catch crucial truths about happiness that escape the quantitative net.

items.title: Competition Designed to Spread Basic Technologies
items.author: By Eric Pfanner
items.abstract: The World Bank is organizing a competition to find solutions that address access to technology in developing countries.

items.title: G-20 Pushes for Measures to End Tax Evasion
items.author: By David Jolly
items.abstract: Finance ministers and central bankers of the Group of 20 countries met to discuss a coordinated effort to stop international tax evasion by calling on governments to share relevant bank information.

items.title: Street Smarts: From Holland, Bright Ideas for Highways
items.author: By Paul Hockenos
items.abstract: Under a Dutch plan, “smart” roads would include glow-in-the-dark markings, interactive streetlights, battery-charging e-lanes and illuminated foul-weather warnings.

items.title: Fighting Words Against Big Data
items.author: By Janet Maslin
items.abstract: The computer scientist Jaron Lanier provides insights on technology in his new book, “Who Owns the Future?”

items.title: Can Technology and Tourism Sustain Mexico’s Sea Turtles?
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: In a new documentary, students explore efforts to conserve endangered sea turtles in a region focused on fishing.

items.title: This Week in Small Business: Small Data
items.author: By Gene Marks
items.abstract: Why small business are wasting money on “big” data. How to procrastinate like a boss. The African-American start-up gap. And do you swear at the office?

items.title: Ray of Light in European Economic Data
items.author: By Jack Ewing
items.abstract: A slight improvement in economic data fed hope that the euro zone was just in a temporary downturn, and not stuck in a recession that could last years.

items.title: U.S. May Quit Giving Aid for Outdated Technology
items.author: By Edward Wyatt
items.abstract: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the F.C.C., said Monday that the commission is considering ways to better prioritize the fund, created through a tax on long-distance services.

items.title: Border Patrol Seeks to Add Digital Eyes to Its Ranks
items.author: By Julia Preston
items.abstract: The Border Patrol is focusing on concentrating Border Patrol agents, equipped with late-model surveillance tools, in areas of frequent illegal traffic, while using aerial drones to monitor remote, lightly trafficked spots.

items.title: Candy Crush Maker King Digital Set to Trade at $22.50, a Midpoint
items.author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Mark Scott
items.abstract: It will remain to be seen if investors are convinced that the , valued at more than $7 billion when it starts trading on Wednesday, can come up with new hits.

items.title: Technology That Transforms Life (and Mutual Funds’ Returns)
items.author: By Tim Gray
items.abstract: Cloud computing, personalized medicine, robotics and other tech innovations brought big returns for some mutual funds in the first quarter.

items.title: More Deportations Follow Minor Crimes, Records Show
items.author: By Ginger Thompson and Sarah Cohen
items.abstract: Two-thirds of the nearly two million people deported since President Obama took office had committed only minor infractions or had no criminal record, a New York Times analysis has found.

items.title: Trying to Dam a Digital Sea
items.author: By Bina Shah
items.abstract: Pakistan’s ban on YouTube has exposed a struggle over freedom of expression.

items.title: Huge New York Development Project Becomes a Data Science Lab
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: The developers of the Hudson Yards on Manhattan’s West Side are forming a partnership with the researchers at N.Y.U.’s Center for Urban Science and Progress to create a “quantified community” that uses data science to study and improve the urban environment.

items.title: Taming the Digital Wild West
items.author: By Eric T. Schneiderman
items.abstract: The web may be changing business, but regulations still apply.

items.title: U.S. Says It Built Digital Programs Abroad With an Eye to Politics
items.author: By Ron Nixon
items.abstract: The United States built Twitter-like programs in Afghanistan and Pakistan, but like a similar program in Cuba, they were shut down for lack of money, officials said.
keywords: United States Agency for International Development

items.title: Values and Data Meet at a Vatican Workshop on Sustaining Humanity on a Flourishing Planet
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: The Vatican hosts a meeting considering the mix of science, technology and values-laden choices that will determine the quality of life — human and otherwise — on Earth in coming decades.

items.title: Should Schools Teach Personality?
items.author: By Anna North
items.abstract: Traits like “grit,” more associated with personality than with intelligence per se, are capturing the attention of educators. But can they really be taught?

items.title: Cisco Makes Its Annual Predictions on Mobile Data Traffic
items.author: By Quentin Hardy
items.abstract: Cisco’s annual outlook for mobile traffic projects a tenfold increase in mobile traffic, at higher speeds, between 2014 and 2019. Even more traffic is expected to go over Wi-Fi networks.

items.title: ‘The Age of Dignity,’ by Ai-jen Poo With Ariane Conrad
items.author: By Louise Aronson
items.abstract: Changing how society deals with caregiving.

items.title: ClassPass and the Joy and Guilt of the Digital Middleman Economy
items.author: By Jenna Wortham
items.abstract: Should I feel bad about using my new favorite app?

items.title: In Forecasting Health Costs, Let Technology Be Your Guide
items.author: By Austin Frakt
items.abstract: The ability to sustain lower growth in costs will depend in large part on how investments in health care technology are encouraged.
keywords: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

items.title: Tuning Out Digital Buzz, for an Intimate Communion With Art
items.author: By Holland Cotter
items.abstract: Nothing can substitute for physically experiencing an artwork, despite the convenience of viewing it online.

items.title: When the Fine Art Market Goes Online
items.author: By Scott Reyburn
items.abstract: Even some big sellers like Christie’s and Sotheby’s are becoming more comfortable with online auctions.

items.title: Eurozone Business Growth Nears 4-Year High, Report Shows
items.author: By David Jolly
items.abstract: Purchasing managers reported that output in March expanded at the quickest pace since May 2011, according to a Markit Economics survey.

items.title: Auctioning the Relics of Technology Pioneers
items.author: By Scott Reyburn
items.abstract: An Alan Turing manuscript sells for $1 million as interest in artifacts grows.

items.title: AOL, a Digital Pioneer, With Another Chance to Reshape Itself
items.author: By Emily Steel and Michael J. de la Merced
items.abstract: Acquisitions were once a symbol of the company, but the onetime Internet titan had in recent years been dogged by rumors of deals it should pursue.

items.title: Art, Technology and Online Identity
items.author: By Rob Sharp
items.abstract: An exhibition at the Whitechapel Gallery in London explores how the digital age has influenced artists.

items.title: Review: When the Digital World Is Judging Your Every Thought
items.author: By Dwight Garner
items.abstract: Jarett Kobek’s “I Hate the Internet” is a grainy political and cultural rant, a sustained shriek about power and morality in a new global era.

items.title: China’s Carbon Emissions May Have Peaked, but It’s Hazy
items.author: By Edward Wong
items.abstract: There could be important consequences if such emissions are falling more than a decade earlier than expected, but finding the answer is difficult.

items.title: Earth to Audience: How Andrew Revkin’s Blog Built a Digital Conversation About Climate Change
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: Dot Earth invites readers around the world to advise, comment, post videos and even argue — to a point.

items.title: Failure to Share Data Hampers War on Boko Haram in Africa
items.author: By Eric Schmitt and Dionne Searcey
items.abstract: American intelligence services have struggled at times to provide information quickly about militants without violating restrictions on what can be shared.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: The Digital Afterlife of Lost Family Photos
items.author: By Teju Cole
items.abstract: What happens when precious repositories of intimacy are scattered or sold — and then found by a stranger?

items.title: Samsung Profit Rises on New Smartphone Screen Technology
items.author: By Paul Mozur
items.abstract: The South Korean technology conglomerate posted its best quarterly profit figure in two years as its phones held their own against Apple.

items.title: Tor Project, a Digital Privacy Group, Reboots With New Board
items.author: By Nicole Perlroth
items.abstract: The former public face of the nonprofit promoter of anonymizing software was pushed out under a cloud of sexual misconduct allegations.

items.title: N.F.L.-Backed Youth Program Says It Reduced Concussions. The Data Disagrees.
items.author: By Alan Schwarz
items.abstract: The Heads Up Football program has been sold to youth football leagues and parents as statistically proven to reduce injuries, but a review of the evidence tells a different story.

items.title: Falcons, Drones, Data: A Winery Battles Climate Change
items.author: By David Gelles
items.abstract: Jackson Family Wines is among California winemakers employing both high-tech and old-school techniques to adapt to hotter, drier conditions.

items.title: Mounds of Injury Data Can’t Bury Brutality of the N.F.L.
items.author: By Michael Powell
items.abstract: On questions about brain injuries and career-threatening knee injuries, the league is hobbling sideways in its attempt to justify a dangerous game.

items.title: Retail Payrolls Sustain a New Blow as Shopping Habits Shift
items.author: By Patricia Cohen
items.abstract: General merchandise stores shed 34,700 jobs in March, a new sign of the challenges facing brick-and-mortar merchants with the rise of online commerce.

items.title: Key to Improving Subway Service in New York? Modern Signals
items.author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
items.abstract: New York’s subway is struggling with old infrastructure and overcrowding. The M.T.A.’s failure to modernize its signal system is a crucial example.

items.title: A Smart, Heartbreaking Novel at the Crossroads of Performance and Art
items.author: By Jenny Hendrix
items.abstract: A nakedly autobiographical meditation on art, Barbara Browning’s “The Gift” both mentions and belongs to the recent crop of autofiction.
keywords: The Gift (Or, Techniques of the Body) (Book)

items.title: Projected Drop in Medicaid Spending Heightens Hurdle for G.O.P. Health Bill
items.author: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan
items.abstract: A Congressional Budget Office analysis showing a 35 percent decrease after two decades created a fresh challenge for Republican leaders trying to muster support for their repeal bill.
keywords: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

items.title: Scientists in Mexico Scramble to Deploy Seismic Sensors
items.author: By Natalie Schachar
items.abstract: Two destructive earthquakes have lent urgency to the country’s plans to build an underwater seismic network.

items.title: Careers for Women in Technology Companies Are a Global Challenge
items.author: By Alina Tugend
items.abstract: While companies in the United States are the ones that make headlines because of gender issues, women say the problems exist elsewhere as well.

items.title: The Great Concierge Debate: Digital or Personal?
items.author: By Mike Seely
items.abstract: Online services like When in Roam try to tailor itineraries to each traveler, using professional concierges. But hotel concierges favor face time.

items.title: New York Times Co. Reports Solid Digital Growth as Print Slides
items.author: By Sydney Ember
items.abstract: Digital advertising and online subscriptions helped offset continued declines in print advertising in the third quarter. Total revenue increased 6 percent, to $386 million.

items.title: Ending the Shutdown: A Sellout or a Smart Move?
items.abstract: Readers discuss whether the Democrats should have held out. One says they are “beyond naïve” to believe Republican promises.
keywords: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)

items.title: When You’re a ‘Digital Nomad,’ the World Is Your Office
items.author: By Kyle Chayka
items.abstract: A global network of live-work spaces is springing up to serve this new breed of millennial wanderer.

items.title: Driverless Car Technology
items.abstract: A reader writes that while engineers work out gaping holes in the technology, we should turn our attention to fixing mass transit.

items.title: A Numbers Guy Left the Front Office to Coach Prospects. Here’s What He Learned.
items.author: By Tyler Kepner
items.abstract: Sig Mejdal, the Houston Astros’ top analyst, spent a season with the Tri-City ValleyCats, and he came away convinced that young players crave the information that tech-savvy teams can offer.

items.title: How to Talk About the World Cup and Sound Reasonably Smart
items.author: By Daniel Gendler and Jonah Engel Bromwich
items.abstract: Don’t know anything about soccer, but know you’ll be forced to care? We’ve got you covered.

items.title: Want Reliable Medical Information? The Trump Administration Doesn’t
items.author: By The Editorial Board
items.abstract: The government has shut down a dependable database on health science.

items.title: How Syrians Pioneered Digital Tools to Stand Up to Authorities
items.author: By Anne Barnard
items.abstract: Smartphone video, now used to document abuses across the globe, has been crucial in telling the outside world about Syria’s war, says Anne Barnard, Beirut bureau chief for The Times.

items.title: Why Friday’s G.D.P. Number May Be a Size Too Big
items.author: By Ben Casselman
items.abstract: Second-quarter economic growth could register above 4 percent. But the figure may have been driven by one-time factors that will be offset later.

items.title: What’s Happening in the Economy? Here’s a Guide to the Data
items.author: By Stephen Grocer
items.abstract: Hand-wringing over a possible slowdown only adds to the importance of the latest releases.

items.title: India Can Hide Unemployment Data, but Not the Truth
items.author: By Kaushik Basu
items.abstract: The jobs situation may be even worse than was suspected.

items.title: Ford Is Investigating Emissions and Fuel Efficiency Data
items.author: By Natasha Singer
items.abstract: The company has hired a law firm to look into how it tested vehicles after employees reported possible flaws with its computer models.

items.title: After Hitting Rock Bottom, the Orioles Turn to Data, and a New G.M.
items.author: By Tyler Kepner
items.abstract: After a 47-115 disaster last season, the Orioles hired Mike Elias from the Astros for a complete rebuild. First step: embracing analytics.

items.title: The Lewis and Clark of the Digital Building Frontier
items.author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
items.abstract: These married architects are democratizing the 3-D printing process, using materials destined for the trash heap — like curry powder and coffee grounds — in place of drywall and foam.

items.title: Reading to Your Toddler? Print Books Are Better Than Digital Ones
items.author: By Perri Klass, M.D
items.abstract: “The tablet itself made it harder for parents and children to engage in the rich back-and-forth turn-taking that was happening in print books,” a researcher said.

items.title: How The Times Thinks About Privacy
items.author: By A. G. Sulzberger
items.abstract: We’re examining our policies and practices around data, too.

items.title: The Devastating Consequences of Being Poor in the Digital Age
items.author: By Mary Madden
items.abstract: When someone who is living paycheck to paycheck falls victim to an online fraud or a breach, the cascade of repercussions can be devastating.

items.title: The Week in Tech: Data Doesn’t Support Sri Lanka’s Social Media Blackout
items.author: By Jamie Condliffe
items.abstract: Social media platforms have a role in inciting violence, but there’s little evidence to suggest that shutting them down prevents escalation.

items.title: Pay Is Rising Fastest for Low Earners. One Reason? Minimum Wages.
items.author: By Ernie Tedeschi
items.abstract: Increases in minimum wages across the country may make the labor market look a bit rosier than it really is.

items.title: China’s Improving Economic Data Masks Deeper Problems
items.author: By Alexandra Stevenson
items.abstract: Consumers are spending, and Beijing reached a trade deal with the U.S., but the Chinese economy still faces a difficult addiction to borrowing.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Make Smart Donations
items.author: By Susan Shain, Shola Lawal and Brad Plumer
items.abstract: Also this week, African climate activists and a popular Berkeley class

items.title: Stories to Sweep You Away: Our New Feature, The Great Read
items.author: By Bill Wasik
items.abstract: Every weekday, we recommend one piece of exceptional writing from across the newsroom. You never know what you’ll find. And that’s the point.

items.title: Data Driving New Approaches to Transportation
items.author: By Norman Mayersohn
items.abstract: Analyzing digital streams of information from electric scooters and motor-assisted bicycles is helping solve travel congestion issues.

items.title: A.I. Is Helping Scientists Understand an Ocean’s Worth of Data
items.author: By Tatiana Schlossberg
items.abstract: Machine-learning applications are proving to be especially useful to the scientific community studying the planet’s largest bodies of water.

items.title: The Economic Data Is About to Get Weird
items.author: By Neil Irwin
items.abstract: Just when we need reliable information the most, the signals are likely to be muddled.

items.title: Helping the Environment, One Small Sensor at a Time
items.author: By Ellen Rosen
items.abstract: New York City nonprofits are using a cloud-based service from the start-up Temboo that helps monitor storm-water runoff and other environmental factors.

items.title: Air Travel Surges by 123%! (Beware of Misleading Data Like That)
items.author: By Neil Irwin
items.abstract: In normal times, percentage change is a helpful guide to what’s happening in the economy. But these are not normal times.

items.title: Can Technology Help Us Eat Better?
items.author: By Anahad O'Connor
items.abstract: A new crop of digital health companies is using blood glucose monitors to transform the way we eat.

items.title: The Smart Way to Grow Roses
items.author: By Margaret Roach
items.abstract: It’s the season for ordering roses. Here’s how to choose the right ones — and how to grow them sustainably once you’ve got them.

items.title: The Joyce Theater Announces Its First Full Digital Season
items.author: By Peter Libbey
items.abstract: Several performances this spring, including a new work by Ayodele Casel, will be recorded onstage at this dance dedicated theater.

items.title: Technology After the Pandemic
items.author: By Michael J. de la Merced
items.abstract: Few investors have a broader view of the global tech landscape than Bob van Dijk. What does he see?

items.title: In Coinbase’s Rise, a Reminder: Cryptocurrencies Use Lots of Energy
items.author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
items.abstract: The company’s stock market arrival establishes Bitcoin and other digital currencies in the traditional financial landscape. It also elevates a technology with astonishing environmental costs.

items.title: Cuomo Aides Spent Months Hiding Nursing Home Death Toll
items.author: By J. David Goodman, Jesse McKinley and Danny Hakim
items.abstract: Aides to the New York governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, repeatedly prevented state health officials from releasing the number of nursing home deaths in the pandemic.

items.title: From the Wastewater Drain, Solid Pandemic Data
items.author: By Emily Anthes
items.abstract: The coronavirus could turn sewage surveillance into a mainstream public health practice.

items.title: E.U. Delays Digital Levy as Tax Talks Proceed
items.author: By Alan Rappeport
items.abstract: The postponement came as Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrived in Brussels to continue pushing for a global minimum tax.

items.title: Dividing lines harden as the Fed contemplates issuing a digital dollar.
items.author: By Jeanna Smialek
items.abstract: Some Fed officials think the central bank needs to get in the digital currency game, while others fret about crowding out the private sector.

items.title: The Godmother of the Digital Image
items.author: By Siobhan Roberts
items.abstract: The mathematician Ingrid Daubechies’ pioneering work in signal processing helped make our electronic world possible — and beat a path for women in the field.

items.title: Unemployment is falling fast, adding pressure for interest rate increases.
items.author: By Jeanna Smialek
items.abstract: The jobless rate is falling sharply and pay is jumping. That may increase the urgency as the Federal Reserve withdraws economic support.

items.title: Inflation Continued to Run Hot and Consumer Spending Fell in December
items.author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
items.abstract: Prices are rising rapidly, wages are growing and consumers are glum as a fraught economic moment poses big challenges for policymakers.

items.title: Private Data Shows Broadway’s Hits and Misses After Reopening
items.author: By Michael Paulson
items.abstract: Big shows did well when they returned in the fall after the long pandemic shutdown but new plays struggled, previously undisclosed industry data shows.
keywords: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (Play)

items.title: January Jobs Report May Disappoint. It Is Sure to Perplex.
items.author: By Ben Casselman
items.abstract: Omicron’s impact is likely to be reflected unevenly in the data, and normal seasonal patterns may have been upended.

items.title: Local Papers Find Hints of Success With Online Subscriptions
items.author: By Marc Tracy
items.abstract: The numbers still pale in comparison with print’s heyday, but the increase is giving some publishers an unusual feeling: hope.

items.title: The U.S. extends technology restrictions to Belarus and the Russian oil industry.
items.author: By Ana Swanson
items.abstract: The Biden administration said the measures would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: How to Make Your Second Home Smarter, Safer and More Sustainable
items.author: By Jon Chase and Rachel Cericola
items.abstract: From security systems to thermostats to window treatments, modern technology can take the anxiety out of maintaining a home from afar.

items.title: What the Silicon Valley Prophet Sees on the Horizon
items.author: By John Markoff
items.abstract: Stewart Brand coined the term “personal computer” and was one of the first to envision what digital technology would become. He knows it got messy. He thinks tech can clean itself up.

items.title: AI’s Best Trick Yet Is Showering Us With Attention
items.author: By Sophie Haigney
items.abstract: Face filters and selfie apps are so compelling because they simulate limitless interest in what we look like.

items.title: White House Aims to Reflect the Environment in Economic Data
items.author: By Lydia DePillis
items.abstract: The Biden administration has set out to measure the economic value of ecosystems, offering new statistics to weigh in policy decisions.

items.title: A Smarter Way to Reduce Gun Deaths
items.author: By Nicholas Kristof
items.abstract: To break the paralysis, focus less on guns and more on those firing them.

items.title: Rethinking the “Digital Detox”
items.author: By Sarah Kessler and Bernhard Warner
items.abstract: Experts say the best way to set boundaries with technology involve sustained effort, not just a break.

items.title: Vice C.E.O.’s Departure Signals Fallen Hopes for Digital Media
items.author: By Benjamin Mullin
items.abstract: Nancy Dubuc is leaving the media company, which is exploring a sale of some or all of the business, after nearly five years there.

items.title: Russia Is Importing Western Weapons Technology, Bypassing Sanctions
items.author: By Ana Swanson and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
items.abstract: Western technology goods are winding up in Russian missiles, raising questions about the efficacy of sanctions.

items.title: The Unemployment Gap Between Black and White New Yorkers Is Widening
items.author: By Stefanos Chen
items.abstract: The unemployment rate for Black New Yorkers rose to 12.2 percent in the first quarter of the year, while the white unemployment rate dropped to 1.3 percent, a new report says.

items.title: A Once-Promising Green Energy Technology Hits a Roadblock
items.author: By Ian Austen
items.abstract: Tidal power turbines operating on the Bay of Fundy in Nova Scotia were suspended after the company running them was unable to get a permit to continue testing.

items.title: Our Covid Data Project Is Over, but the Need for Timely Data Is Not
items.author: By Beth Blauer, Lauren Gardner, Sheri Lewis and Lainie Rutkow
items.abstract: Three years ago we were caught flat-footed, and many people died.
keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
